A disaster plan is developed for a group of people at a facility that details what needs to be done, how, when, and by whom before and after the time an anticipated disastrous event is expected to occur. There is no such thing as an unscheduled event plan. Incident command plan is a management concept designed to clarify command relationships from different responding agencies during a disaster or mass casualty event requiring a multi-jurisdictional response. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 85, 112

questions.stem: The flight crew is called to transport a 6-year-old child following a submersion injury. The child is awake, alert, and breathing spontaneously but was reported to have been underwater for 2 minutes and required CPR when EMS arrived. Which intervention should the flight nurse perform before transport?
options: Administer 20 mL/kg of isotonic fluid bolus
questions.rationale: Although the child's respiratory condition requires close monitoring over the next few days, their alertness and wakefulness are reassuring signs despite the drowning incident. A cervical collar should be placed in case a fall or diving injury caused the drowning incident. If vital signs are stable, a fluid bolus can be withheld unless the patient shows signs of decompensation. Reference: Nelson's Essentials of Pediatrics, 6th ed., p. 1044.

questions.stem: For informed consent, in addition to explaining the risks and benefits to the patient, the transport nurse should also include
options: signs and symptoms leading to the need for the procedure
the length of time of the procedure
questions.rationale: Informed consent includes all of the following essential components: description of procedure to be performed; available alternatives to procedure; risks and benefits of procedure and alternatives; patient understanding of procedure, alternatives, and associated risks/benefits of all; practitioner or physician presence during consent administration. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 124-125

questions.stem: While preparing for transfer, the flight nurse fails to properly secure the patient to the transport sled. During a hard landing, the patient sustains injuries. The nurse could be found guilty of:
questions.rationale: Malpractice is committed when all of the required elements are present: presence of duty, breach of duty, foreseeability, causation, injury and damages. Foreseeability and causation are elements that must be present for malpractice to occur, but are not the actual violation. Malfeasance is a type of breach of duty caused by an act of commission. The question describes nonfeasance, or an act of omission. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 5/74

questions.stem: The flight crew is transporting a patient with a diagnosis of MI to a specialty resource hospital. When comparing the patient's presenting ECG to the flight crew's ECG, the crew interprets the presence of Q-waves greater than 1 mm wide with a deflection half the height and depth of the entire complex. The flight crew recognizes the ECG changes as
questions.rationale: Presence of a Q-wave has been associated with transmural AMI; however, studies now demonstrate that both Q-wave (STEMI) and non-Q-wave (non-STEMI) infarcts can be transmural or subendocardial. In general, Q-wave infarctions are associated with a larger region of myocardial necrosis, higher enzyme levels, fresh coronary thrombosis, frequent vomiting, congestive HF, conduction defects, dysrhythmias, and loss collateral circulation. Reference: Sheehy's Manual of Emergency Care, 8th Edition (2024), p. 241

questions.stem: A tree trimmer, who was electrocuted after making contact with an overhead power line, has full-thickness burns on the right hand and foot and a painful, tight right forearm. During transport, the patient is screaming and writhing in pain despite several doses of analgesics. The cardiac monitor shows sinus rhythm with frequent multifocal PVCs. The flight nurse PRIORITIZES which intervention:
options: Elevate right arm to the level of the heart
Apply a cold compress to the right arm
Emergent escharotomy of the right forearm
questions.rationale: Electrical burns pose a risk of compartment syndrome. This patient reports extreme pain, even though their contact burns are full-thickness and treatable. The abnormal appearance of their forearm needs careful monitoring. The arm should be elevated to heart level to enhance blood flow. While electrical burns also carry a risk of cardiac instability and arrhythmias, the PVCs currently do not require intervention. If conservative management does not improve the condition of the right arm, a fasciotomy should be considered as the next step. An escharotomy is only necessary in cases of full-thickness circumferential burns. Applying a cold compress is contraindicated for this injury. Reference: Trauma Nursing: From Resuscitation Through Rehabilitation, 5th Ed. (2019), p. 620.

questions.stem:
The flight nurse responds to a patient from Florida who arrived at a mountain resort area two days prior. The patient complains of severe headache, fatigue and dyspnea at rest. Vital signs are:

HR 115 beats/min

RR 28 breaths/min with dry cough

BP 142/88 mmHg

SpO2 68% (2L nasal cannula)

What disorder is this patient likely suffering from and what (apart from oxygen administration) is the most beneficial treatment for this patient?
questions.rationale: HAPS can occur at altitudes between 8000-10000 feet and is usually associated with rate of ascent to altitude and typically occurs 2 days after arrival at altitude. Presentation is dyspnea at rest, a dry cough, rales, tachypnea and tachycardia. The treatment is oxygen and descent to increase the partial pressure of oxygen. If there is a change in the level of consciousness or development of seizures then HACE must be ruled out. Reference: Rosen's Emergency Medicine: Concepts & Clinical Practice, 9th edition (2018), p. 1793

questions.stem: When evaluating a landing zone during a scene response, the HIGHEST priority for the flight crew is:
questions.rationale: Safety is the flight crew's chief priority. When evaluating a potential landing zone, identifying obstructions is one of the steps to ensure the scene is safe. Ensuring ground personnel contact, communicating with dispatch, and monitoring wind direction are each important but not the highest priority in evaluating the landing zone from the air. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 108

questions.stem: A flight team is dispatched to transport a patient with circumferential full-thickness burns to the chest. The patient is intubated and placed on a ventilator. The flight nurse notes the peak inspiratory pressure to be 45 cm H2O. Which of the following is the BEST intervention for this finding?
options: Switch the mode to pressure control
questions.rationale: Due to the loss of elasticity of the tissue following a burn, it may become difficult to ventilate a patient. Performing escharotomies will enable effective ventilation. Although suctioning the patient may help with oxygenation, it will not change the lung compliance. As this is a burn patient with bilateral breath sounds, a tube thoracostomy is not indicated at this point. Changing the mode to pressure control will not change the decreased lung compliance caused by the circumferential burns to the chest. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 282

questions.stem: The flight crew is transporting an infant who was delivered at 34 weeks and presents with increasing lethargy and cool skin. The PRIORITY laboratory assessment should be
questions.rationale: Preterm newborns are prone to hypoglycemia due to impaired glycogen storage. This child may not have enough glycogen stored to maintain a normal blood glucose level, as most glycogen storage occurs during the third trimester. Lactate, sodium, and PaCO2 are not the priority labs used to identify the immediate life threat. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 4/73

questions.stem: The transport team has been called to a Labor and Delivery unit to transport a 32-week pregnant patient with gestational diabetes, Group B strep, and influenza to a tertiary facility. While receiving report, which of the following findings would lead the transport nurse to suspect that labor is imminent?
questions.rationale: Cervical dilation exceeding 4 cm indicates impending labor, regardless of previous pregnancies. A -3 fetal station indicates the presenting part is situated 3 cm above the ischial spines and has not yet entered the true pelvis. A cervical effacement of 20% is considered mild and usually does not indicate significant progression toward labor. Normal moderate variability in fetal heart rate is expected and does not imply that labor is imminent. The flight nurse can expect preterm infants to deliver at less than 10 cm dilation. Reference: Advanced Critical Care for the Transport Professional, 1st Ed. (2024), p. 155.

questions.stem: The flight nurse has responded to a patient who was trapped in a burning house. On initial assessment, singed facial hair, erythema of the oropharynx and carbonaceous sputum is noted. Which pathophysiologic change should be INITIALLY anticipated when managing the ventilation of this patient?
questions.rationale: Noxious chemicals from combustion adhere to the surface of the smoke particles and cause direct damage to the airway epithelium, especially in the smaller airways and terminal bronchi which impairs oxygen exchange. Inhalation injuries do not usually cause spontaneous pneumothorax although aggressive positive pressure ventilation could cause a pneumothorax. Pneumonia would be a more delayed concern. Inhalation injuries cause hypoxia versus hypercarbia. Reference: Transport Professional Advanced Trauma Course, 6th Ed. (2018), p. 107

questions.stem: After arriving on scene of a rollover accident on the highway involving a tractor-trailer marked with hazardous materials placards, the Incident Commander directs the flight team to:
options: Don Level D personal protective equipment and begin treatment in the warm zone
Initiate universal personal protective equipment (PPE) and begin treatment in the cold zone
Stage in the landing zone, pending identification of the hazardous materials
Don Level A personal protective equipment and begin triage in the warm zone
questions.rationale: Patients in the cold zone have already been decontaminated, thus universal PPE is appropriate. The warm zone is where decontamination takes place; as such, the flight suit, which is a form of Level D PPE, is not adequate protection. Level A PPE is the highest level protection with a fully encapsulated suit and self-contained air supply; these are reserved for the highest trained hazardous materials technicians. Identifying the hazardous materials is important, but treatment can begin as soon as decontamination takes place. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 6th Ed. (2024), p. 71-72

questions.stem: The flight crew is flying over water when the pilot informs the team that there is an in-flight emergency, and his intention is to 'ditch the helicopter.' The flight nurse knows it is important to:
options: Release the seatbelt prior to impact
Kick feet during to clear doors
Allow the helicopter to completely invert before trying to exit
Exit the helicopter immediately after impact
questions.rationale: During a water landing in a helicopter, it is important to wait for the craft to fully invert and all but fill with water prior to attempting egress. Trying to exit prior to this can lead to the helicopter capsizing on top of you or getting obstructed by the blades and debris. Kicking is to be avoided during egress as you could inadvertently become tangled or injure a coworker. You should not release your seat belt prior to impact to avoid being ejected or thrown about the cabin. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 6th Ed. (2024), p. 144

questions.stem:
The nurse is transporting a 78-year-old patient from a community ED to a tertiary hospital for altered mental status. Prolonged QT segments are observed on the monitor. The head CT was negative and the toxicology screen was also negative. Medication history includes Trandate (Labetalol), Lasix (Furosemide), and Aspirin. The blood chemistries are included on the transfer form:

Glucose: 149 mg/dL

Calcium: 9.1 mg/dL

PCO2: 29 mmHg

Chloride: 105 mEq/L

Sodium: 136 mEq/L

Potassium: 2.0 mEq/L

Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 30 mg/dL

Creatinine: 1.5 mg/dL

The correct action for the nurse is to:
questions.rationale: The elderly patient usually is on many medications and may take them incorrectly. This patient took too much Lasix causing a dangerous drop in Potassium. The patient can have fatal arrhythmias due to QT prolongation and is not the priority. Calcium is within the normal range, therefore calcium gluconate is not the priority. Reference: Sheehy's Emergency Nursing: Principles and Practice, 7th Edition (2019), p. 5/78

questions.stem: What term describes stress that is considered normal, encountered in daily living, and may enhance function, heighten awareness, or provide new perspectives?
questions.rationale: Eustress is a type of stress that is nonthreatening and generally makes humans perform better. Distress involves noxious stimuli. Somatization and cognitive are not types of stress. Reference: AACN Core Curriculum for High Acuity, Progressive, and Critical Care Nursing (2016), p. 703

questions.stem: During resuscitation of a polytrauma patient, the flight nurse knows what lab value is indicative of impaired perfusion and increased mortality rate.
questions.rationale: Elevated lactate (greater than 4 mmol/L) is indicative of increased anaerobic metabolism and indicative of oxygen deficit within the tissues, which shows a decrease in perfusion. Potassium and sodium are not indicative of poor perfusion. Base excess of -2 is within a normal range. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 208

questions.stem: While transporting a pregnant patient in preterm labor, the transport nurse notes fetal bradycardia and finds a prolapsed umbilical cord. Initial intervention should include
options: manual displacement of the presenting part
attempted replacement of the umbilical cord
questions.rationale: Elevation of the presenting part with a hand in the vagina is done to prevent further cord compression. Positioning in Trendelenburg or the knee-chest position can also be attempted. Supine maternal positioning will not help and may additionally cause maternal hypotension due to supine hypotension syndrome. Attempted replacement of the umbilical cord would be dangerous. Although the cord may spontaneously retract, the cord should never be manually replaced because severe compression may occur. Tocolysis is indicated to slow contractions and reduce the pressure on the cord. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 449

questions.stem: When administering medications to the geriatric patient population, the flight nurse understands that:
options: The patient has less fat reserves, so larger doses should be administered
The patient is less sensitive to medications, so larger doses should be administered
The patient's liver function is lower, so lower doses should be administered
The patient has not increased kidney function, so smaller doses should be administered
questions.rationale: The older adult generally has lower function of end organs and increased fat reserves. Medications should be given carefully as they will not be metabolized as quickly as in the younger adult population. Reference: Critical Care Nursing: Diagnosis & Management, 8th Ed. (2018), p. 1005

questions.stem: On arrival to the scene of a high-speed MVC, the flight crew receives a patient lying in the ambulance that is pregnant at 32-weeks gestation. The patient is awake and alert, complaining of sharp suprapubic pain. The patient reports a maternal history of G2, P1 and received prenatal care. The patient has a previous history of a c-section. Assessment reveals asymmetrical uterus and rebound tenderness. Based on this assessment, the nurse is concerned for which of the following conditions?
questions.rationale: Classic signs of uterine rupture are an asymmetric uterus, suprapubic pain, and palpable fetal parts. Ovarian lacerations typically present with signs and symptoms of retroperitoneal bleeding. Classic signs and symptoms of abruptio placenta are dark red vaginal bleeding, a board-like uterus, and a rising fundal height. Preterm labor does not fit this clinical picture. Reference: Trauma Nursing Core Course, 9th ed. (2024), p. 336.

questions.stem: The flight nurse is called to a community hospital for a neonate in distress. The newborn is cyanotic and has an oxygen saturation of 60% on room air which worsened with high-flow oxygen. Prior to transport, the nurse should request administration of:
questions.rationale: This infant is likely suffering from a transposition of the great arteries. The ductus arteriosus needs to be kept open until surgical correction can be performed. Prostaglandins should be administered cautiously, as it can cause apnea. These patients usually require intubation. The other medications would not be indicated in this case. Reference: Nelson's Essentials of Pediatrics, p. 569.

questions.stem: The transport team is on scene of a chemical release at a manufacturing plant. The team notices numerous patients walking towards them vomiting and exhibiting urinary and fecal incontinence. The team should:
options: Identify the source of the contaminant
Don level A personal protective equipment
Properly administer Atropine to the patients
questions.rationale: The patients are exhibiting signs and symptoms of exposure to organophosphate pesticides or nerve agent chemicals, thus they need to be decontaminated prior to treatment. Atropine is used as an antidote to organophosphates and nerve agents, the transport team cannot begin treating patients until they are decontaminated. Identifying the source of the contaminant is necessary, but is a lower priority than protecting the transport team's safety. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 47-49

questions.stem: Following an emergency landing, a critical incident stress debriefing is held. Two months later, a flight nurse who was involved in the incident seems uninterested in work, startles easily, and complains of frequent flashbacks and nightmares. Which of the following should the manager do?
options: Arrange for the nurse to receive individual counseling
Evaluate the nurse for substance abuse
Remove the nurse from duty immediately
Advise this is a normal stress response for the nurse
questions.rationale: This is not normal stress because it is interfering with daily living. Removing the nurse from duty and having the nurse tested for substance abuse would be punitive in nature and should be avoided. Arranging for individual counseling for the nurse to work through the issue with a professional counselor fits with current practices of CISM. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 802

questions.stem: During transport, a patient suffers cardiopulmonary arrest. The flight nurse proceeds with intubation to secure an airway. Which method of assessment for determining proper ETT placement is BEST in this situation?
options: Absence of air movement in stomach
questions.rationale: Proper ETCO2 waveform is the best method of assessment. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 1/6

questions.stem: The flight nurse enters an ambulance and finds several paramedics and police officers attempting to restrain a combative patient who is actively bleeding from a self-inflicted wrist laceration. The patient is resisting care and is stating 'let me die! I want to die!' Which type of consent allows the flight nurse to treat the patient?
questions.rationale: A patient who is suicidal and in police custody or under a physician's emergency commitment can not refuse life-saving treatments. This self-inflicted wound may be fatal without immediate treatment. Patients that are suicidal, homicidal, delusional, or experiencing other psychiatric emergencies may not be able to think rationally and the flight nurse can legally treat the patient, even if resisting care, when acting in good faith. Reference: Sheehy's Manual of Emergency Care, 8th Edition (2024), p. 7

questions.stem: A patient with atrial fibrillation complains of a sudden onset of pain and numbness in the right forearm. The arm is cool to the touch and has a thready radial pulse. The transport nurse should suspect which of the following?
questions.rationale: The nurse should suspect arterial thrombosis. Arterial thrombosis is a common complication of atrial fibrillation. An embolus which mobilizes into the upper extremities would manifest itself with these findings. Venous insufficiency is most commonly associated with the lower extremities and is a chronic condition. Classic findings include venous ulcers, skin discoloration, and enlarged or varicose veins. Compartment syndrome is an acute finding, generally associated with trauma. Long bone fractures are present in as much as 20% of all patients presenting with compartment syndrome. Other causes such as drug abuse, anticoagulant use, and other chronic medical conditions have also been associated with compartment syndrome. Myocardial ischemia is commonly manifested with pain radiating to the left arm and neck, and does not usually cause vascular changes to the upper extremities. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 303

questions.stem: A transport nurse observes blood in the catheter connection tubing of a patient receiving intra-aortic balloon (IABP) therapy. The nurse should FIRST
options: disconnect and manually inflate the balloon
clamp the connection tubing to the balloon catheter
questions.rationale: The presence of blood in the catheter connection tubing is the hallmark of balloon rupture. It requires immediate cessation of pumping and removal of the IABP. Continued use of a ruptured balloon can lead to helium gas embolization, a potentially fatal event. The balloon is most likely ruptured. Although intact balloons that are not actively pumping should be intermittently, manually inflated according to the manufacturer's directions to prevent clot formation, manual inflation of a ruptured balloon will inject gas into the aorta through the defect in the balloon. Flushing and re-zeroing of the arterial line are appropriate only if the balloon is intact. These measures will not clear blood in the catheter tubing. Although the desired action in the presence of balloon rupture is to prevent gas pumping into the balloon, the correct course of action is to cease pumping, not merely clamp the connection tubing. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 331

questions.stem: A flight team is transporting a patient by fixed-wing aircraft at a cruising altitude of 40,000 feet. The flight nurse observes a fog-like mist within the interior of the cabin. The nurse's FIRST action should be to
options: ensure that all passengers and equipment are secured
check outlets and medical equipment for smoke
questions.rationale: The nurse should first begin breathing supplemental oxygen. Mist or 'fog' within the aircraft's cabin at altitude most likely indicates decompression. The nurse should first ensure that he or she is protected from hypoxia as a result of exposure to reduced barometric pressure. Administering oxygen to the patient is a secondary action. Time of useful consciousness at 40,000 feet is 15 seconds or less. If the nurse is disabled by hypoxia, then further helpful actions would not be possible. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 40

questions.stem: In a helicopter safety and landing zone (LZ) presentation to a local EMS service, which of the following is the MOST important instruction for EMS personnel?
options: Approach only from the loading side of the helicopter
Utilize ambulance lights to highlight the LZ
Ensure LZ is at least 200' x 200'
Proceed toward the aircraft only when directed by the pilot
questions.rationale: The scene call environment is one of the most potentially hazardous aspects of air medical operations. Safety is of paramount importance and situational awareness must be maintained when working around an aircraft. Ground personnel should only be allowed to approach the aircraft when directed to do so by the pilot or a flight crew member. The pilot in command of the aircraft must be able to see personnel approaching. Mitigating the hazard from air medical operations on ground personnel is the most important instruction. The LZ can be a minimum of 75' x 75' during the day and 125' x 125' at night. While some situations may require lighting the landing zone, the MOST important instruction for EMS personnel should be to approach only when directed. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 6th Ed. (2024), p. 142

questions.stem: Which of the following cranial nerves is responsible for pupillary response in a closed head injury patient?
questions.rationale: Oculomotor is correct. Oculomotor (CN III) is responsible for pupillary response. Optic Nerve (CN II) is visual acuity, visual fields, reading printed material, and seeing light. Trigeminal is responsible for corneal reflex and facial sensation. Abducens (CN VI) is responsible for extraocular eye movement. Reference: Emergency Nursing Core Curriculum, 7th Ed. (2018), p. 634

questions.stem:
The flight team is called to transport a 6-month-old child diagnosed with febrile seizures. Upon arrival, hospital staff states the child has lost IV access and two additional attempts have been made to initiate access, which have been unsuccessful.

Vital signs:

BP 68/40 mmHg

HR 178 beats/min

RR 36 breaths/min

T(rectal) 103°F (39.4C)

O2 Sat 99% (room air)

The NEXT appropriate stop is:
questions.rationale: This child is presenting with shock, elevated HR and low BP. It is pertinent to obtain access on this child to initiate fluid resuscitation. Intraosseous access can be obtained quickly, and fluid resuscitation can be started without further delay. The other three options would delay fluid administration and therefore could be harmful to the patient outcome. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 2/15

questions.stem: The flight nurse is called to an accident scene where a patient has been trapped under a fallen tree for several hours and has a crushed leg. IV access has been established. As the patient is extracted, the nurse should prepare to administer
questions.rationale: Crush injuries can cause a large release of potassium. Calcium gluconate is used to neutralize the effects of hyperkalemia. Fentanyl can be given after or before for pain control but is not the priority. Normal saline can be given for volume replacement but is again not the priority. Magnesium chloride would not be a correct choice for this patient. Reference: Sheehy's Emergency Nursing: Principles and Practice, 7th Edition (2019), p. 199

questions.stem: During a rotor scene call for a 4-year-old patient, the patient's mother requests to ride along with the patient to the hospital. Which of the following statements by the mother would MOST concern the flight crew?
options: 'I would like to speak to the pilot about safety of the flight'
'If I can't hold my child, they won't go with you'
questions.rationale: The decision to transport a family member is based on multiple factors, and while all of the choices may weigh in the decision, safety of the entire team must be the primary factor. Family members should be instructed that safety regulations require all passengers to wear approved restraint devices (Commercial Flight Rule 135.128). Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 6th Ed. (2024), p. 340

questions.stem: The flight crew is called to transport a 6-year-old child who was hit in the chest with a baseball. The patient has had a chest x-ray that shows no fractures to the sternum or ribs. The flight nurse is MOST concerned about which of the following vital signs?
questions.rationale: Children have flexible ribs that are not fully formed, and therefore may not fracture with blunt injuries. Blunt cardiac injuries cannot be ruled out in a pediatric patient with known chest trauma. Cardiac arrhythmias (ventricular tachycardia/fibrillation) are likely in the patient with blunt chest trauma. Because the pediatric patient cannot compensate with stroke volume changes, a decreased blood pressure is a concerning sign following thoracic trauma. Reference: Trauma Nursing: From Resuscitation Through Rehabilitation, 5th Ed. (2019), p. 687; Wong's Nursing Care of Infants and Children, 12th Ed. (2024), p. 749

questions.stem:
A school-age patient presents after a house fire with 3rd degree circumferential burns of the neck and chest. Physical exam reveals the extent of the burn is 60% total body surface area. The patient also presents with stridor and drooling. Vital signs are:

BP: 90/45 mmHg

HR: 133 beats/min

RR: 28 breaths/min

O2 Sat: 100% (room air)

GCS: 14

The flight nurse understands that the PRIORITY intervention is:
questions.rationale: The patient is demonstrating signs and symptoms of smoke inhalation and younger patients are at greater risk for airway obstruction. Oxygen saturation may be inaccurate due to carbon monoxide exposure from an enclosed area. The priority intervention is to protect the airway and initiate early intubation. IV fluids, dressings, and wound debridement are all indicated for burn resuscitation, but they are not the priority. Reference: Advanced Trauma Life Support Student Course Manual, 10th Ed. (2018), p. 171

questions.stem: The nurse is transporting a patient who has suffered an epidural hematoma. What is the BEST indication of a change in intracranial pressure?
questions.rationale: When assessing the patient with a neurologic injury, level of consciousness is the best indication of changes in ICP. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 253

questions.stem: The flight team responds to a facility for a high risk OB transport of a mother with gestational diabetes. The baby has just been delivered and is born limp. A heel stick reveals a blood glucose of 25 mg/dL and an umbilical line has been placed by the delivery team. Appropriate treatment is to administer:
questions.rationale: Critically ill hypoglycemic neonates require IV glucose infusions of 4-6 mg/kg/min of D10W. The other doses and concentrations are not appropriate for this age group. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 4/74

questions.stem: A patient is being transported by air for direct admission to a medical intensive care unit after ingesting a large quantity of ethylene glycol. After verifying the position of the patient's endotracheal tube and that he is breathing spontaneously, the nurse notes that the ETCO2 is 15 mm Hg. The nurse should anticipate the patient will need emergency
questions.rationale: The nurse should anticipate hemodialysis. Ingestion of more than 1 mL/kg of ethylene glycol can often be fatal. Metabolism of ethylene glycol deposit in the kidney, causing renal failure. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 424

questions.stem: The flight crew is called to the scene of a collision where heavy front end damage to the vehicle has caused the vehicle to catch fire. A back seat passenger reports they were able to self extricate after 10 minutes and reports no physical burns. Upon assessment, the nurse notes the patient has soot to their face, and a dry voice. The MOST appropriate next action is:
options: Monitor for airway compromise from inhalation burns
Triage the patient to the basic life support (BLS) ambulance
Transport the patient to the closest facility
questions.rationale: Soot on the face and raspy voice are indicative of heavy inhalation burns. This patient should be closely monitored for airway compromise and transported to the nearest burns center. IV fluids important, but not the most important intervention. A BLS ambulance is not recommended due to the potential for airway compromise. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 281

questions.stem: The flight nurse is preparing to transport a patient who was injured and has significant swelling and paresthesia to the left upper extremity. Which order by the sending facility should be questioned?
options: Elevate the extremity above the heart
questions.rationale: An extremity with compartment syndrome has reduced blood flow and elevation could further decrease circulation. Immobilization and splinting are appropriate, but caution should be taken not to apply excessive pressure that might impair blood flow. Regular reassessment is necessary to detect any worsening of the condition. The patient may also need analgesics for pain management. Reference: Prehospital Trauma Life Support 10th ed., p. 419

questions.stem:
A patient was a restrained driver in a side-impact motor vehicle accident. On assessment, the patient is awake and verbalizing difficulty breathing. The patient appears pale and diaphoretic, tachypneic, and has decreased breath sounds over left lung field. Bony crepitus is palpated over the left chest. Vital signs are as follows:

BP 78/56 mm Hg

HR 132 beats/min

O2 sat 84%

The flight nurse should suspect the patient may be experiencing:
questions.rationale: Blunt trauma can cause massive hemothorax as a result of rapid accumulation of >1500 ml of blood in the chest cavity. Rapid accumulation of blood results in severe hypotension and hypoxia. The information from the assessment does not provide mechanism of injury for a cardiac tamponade or assessment findings, such as muffled heart tones. Cardiac tamponade patients are not usually hypoxic. The patient could have a pneumothorax but simple pneumothorax patients are not usually pale and hypotensive. The assessment does not demonstrate a floating segment or inward movement of the chest wall during inspiration and outward movement during expiration. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 252

questions.stem: Which of the following is the MOST appropriate intervention to prevent and protect the patient with and to reduce the risk for pulmonary barotrauma from mechanical ventilation?
options: Attempt to lower the plateau pressure
Increase the fraction of inspired oxygen
questions.rationale: Attempting to lower the plateau pressure is the most appropriate intervention. Maintaining a plateau pressure less than or equal to 35 cm H2O is desired. The other interventions are not the most appropriate interventions. Initiating permissive hypocapnia strategies would mean increasing the tidal volume or the respiratory rate. Both actions may further the barotrauma. Decreasing expiration time is not appropriate, because decreasing the inspiration time will increase the peak inspiratory pressure. Increasing the fraction of inspired oxygen will have no effect on barotrauma. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 191

questions.stem: The flight crew is called to the scene of a patient whose right lower extremity is still entrapped by a trash compactor. The flight crew should be aware of which of the following metabolic changes when the extremity is released?
questions.rationale: Crush syndrome is a serious condition that can threaten both life and limbs following crush injuries. It is characterized by reperfusion injury, which occurs when the trapped limb is released, causing myoglobin and potassium to enter the bloodstream. This causes traumatic rhabdomyolysis, damaging the kidneys and increasing the risk of hyperkalemia. Patients with crush syndrome also develop hypocalcemia because calcium is absorbed by injured muscle cells. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 6th Ed. (2024), p. 304

questions.category: Medical Emergencies; Environmental and Toxicological Emergencies
questions.stem: A pediatric near-drowning victim is unresponsive and cyanotic with a pulse of 60 beats/min. The patient is being ventilated via an ET tube. The flight nurse's FIRST action is to
options: add positive end-expiratory pressure to the resuscitator bag
administer 1 mg of atropine via the endotracheal tube
questions.rationale: The flight nurse's first action is to assess ET tube placement. Administering 1 mg of atropine is incorrect because bradycardia is hypoxia related. Adding PEEP to the resuscitator bag or manually overriding the pop-off valve will not improve the heart rate if the tube is not in the correct location. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 5/18

questions.stem: The flight team is transporting a patient on dialysis who has an infected arteriovenous shunt. The patient requires rapid sequence intubation en route. The flight nurse knows which of the following medications is contraindicated as an induction agent?
questions.rationale: Succinylcholine is a depolarizing medication. It can cause an increase in potassium. The patient is already likely to have an increased potassium level due to having kidney failure. The other medications would not cause this increase in potassium. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 179

questions.stem:
The flight crew is called to transport a patient with aortic dissection. Current vital signs are:

HR 52 beats/min

BP 135/70 mmHg

RR 18 breaths/min

SpO2 100% (2L nasal cannula)

The MOST appropriate medication to initiate for this patient is:
questions.rationale: The most important management for patients with aortic injury is blood pressure management, with a goal of 90-120mmHg. Nicardipine will decrease blood pressure without affecting heart rate. Esmolol is contraindicated for this patient due to low heart rate. Epinephrine will increase blood pressure. Fentanyl is important for pain control, but will not affect blood pressure effectively for this patient. Reference: Sheehy's Emergency Nursing: Principles and Practice, 7th Edition (2019), pp. 247

questions.stem:
A patient with a saddle pulmonary embolism has become more lethargic. The patient's vital signs are:

BP 72/47 mm Hg

HR 120 beats/min

RR 28 breaths/min

O2 Sat 80% (room air)

The NEXT appropriate intervention should be to administer which of the following?
questions.rationale: Alteplase (Activase) is correct because it will actively dissolve a clot. The other medications do not dissolve existing clots. Reference: Rosen's Emergency Medicine: Concepts & Clinical Practice, 10th edition (2018), p. 1063

questions.stem: Which of the following medications is BEST for treating an increase in heart rate and blood pressure in a chemically paralyzed patient?
questions.rationale: Although the patient received a neuromuscular blocker (NMB) or paralytic, the NMB will not alter the patient's level of consciousness. Sedation must accompany the NMB or the patient will be chemically paralyzed with the potential of being fully awake. Administration of a short-acting paralytic drug is not appropriate. The change in vital signs is not related to neuromuscular blockade, but is likely due to awareness, beta blockade will manage the symptoms, but not the cause of the tachycardia and hypertension. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 128

questions.stem:
The flight crew is transporting a 140kg patient from the scene of a motor vehicle collision that sustained blunt abdominal trauma. Bruising is noted to the left flank. Vital signs include:

BP: 78/54 mmHg

HR: 162 beats/min

RR: 28 breaths/min

SpO2: 92% (15L nonrebreating mask)

On arrival to the facility, the nurse knows that which diagnostic test will be MOST beneficial?
questions.rationale: A diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL) may be indicated in hemodynamically unstable patients with suspected retroperitoneal bleeding. Due to the patient's vital signs, a CT should not be indicated upon arrival. Clarity of the FAST exam may be limited by body habitus. A KUB x-ray may not reveal bleeding and is less diagnostic in the obese patient. Reference: Advanced Trauma Life Support Student Course Manual, 10th Ed. (2018), p. 90

questions.stem: The nurse is transporting a patient with severe angioedema. An initial attempt at rapid sequence intubation was unsuccessful and the patient's oxygen saturation is now 60%. The next BEST course of action for the nurse to take is to perform
questions.rationale: An immediate surgical cricothyrotomy is required when the nurse is unable to intubate and unable to oxygenate. In patients with edema of the airways, a surgical cricothyrotomy should be performed early before the patient develops a hypoxic cardiac arrest. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 170/1-71

questions.stem: During a 90 minute air transport, the flight team notices their patient on mechanical ventilation is now over-breathing the set rate on the ventilator which was 12 breaths/min. The total rate is now 40 breaths/min. Ventilator mode is Assist Control. Blood pressure was sustaining 105/70 mmHg and is now 65/40 mmHg. The patient was given a neuromuscular blocker (NMB) approximately 90 minutes ago. Heart rate has increased from 80 to 120 beats/min. The nurse recognizes that, in addition to the NMB effects wearing off, the patient is also experiencing:
questions.rationale: This situation is multi-factorial. The patient is on Assist Control for mechanical ventilation. When a patient is over-breathing, if they spontaneously breath, they will get the pre-determined volume, every time, from the ventilator. If the patient is now breathing 28 extra breaths over the set rate of 12, they are getting a total of 40 breaths at the same tidal volume, with each breath, leading to a dangerous situation whereby the patient is unable to fully exhale causing air to remain in the alveoli. This results in a negative feedback loop whereby the extra volume that is unable to be exhaled leads to increased intrathoracic pressure, resulting in decreased venous return and subsequently, further hypotension. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 6th Ed. (2024), p. 212-216

questions.stem: The flight crew is responding to a high-speed motorcycle crash where the patient is not wearing a helmet. Approaching the patient from the left side, the flight crew noted massive facial edema, epistaxis, and a spoon-shaped deformity of the face. What condition should the crew be MOST concerned about?
questions.rationale: Patients with Le Fort III fractures may present with massive edema, ecchymosis, epistaxis, malocclusion, and a spoon-shaped appearance of the face seen from the side profile. Reference: Sheehy's Manual of Emergency Care, 8th Edition (2024), p. 421.

questions.stem: Due to the risk of hyperkalemia, succinylcholine is contraindicated in patients with which of the following conditions?
options: Major burn less than 6 hours after injury
Spinal cord injury greater than 6 months after injury
questions.rationale: Succinylcholine causes potassium to shift out of the cells and into the bloodstream during depolarization. Patients with neuromuscular disorders (such as muscular dystrophy, multiple sclerosis, and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis) have an absolute contraindication for succinylcholine because permanent alterations in their acetylcholine receptors increase their sensitivity to succinylcholine during depolarization, predisposing them to hyperkalemia. During the initial days to months after injury, burns and spinal cord injuries can cause an increased sensitivity of acetylcholine receptors to succinylcholine, leading to an exaggerated shift of potassium during depolarization. Dialysis-dependent renal failure patients that have missed dialysis are potentially hyperkalemic, which could be exacerbated by succinylcholine; stage 3 renal failure patients are not dialysis-dependent. Reference: Rosen's Emergency Medicine: Concepts & Clinical Practice, 10th Edition (2023), p. 14-15

questions.stem: A patient suffers facial trauma during a fall. On the initial assessment by the flight crew, the patient complains of diplopia. The assessment finding is concerning for which of the following?
questions.rationale: Le Fort III fractures involve complete craniofacial separation leading to massive facial edema, mobility and depression of the zygomatic bones, periorbital ecchymosis, and diplopia. On assessment, patients with mandibular fractures may have malocclusion of the jaw, facial asymmetry, palpable step off deformity, and drooling. Assessment findings following a linear skull fracture may include headache, soft tissue injury, and possible decreased loss of consciousness. Assessment findings following a basilar skull fracture may include raccoon eyes, Battle's sign, hemotympanum, and facial nerve palsy. Reference: Trauma Nursing Core Course, 8th edition, Chapter 6

questions.category: Medical Emergencies; Infectious and Communicable Diseases
questions.stem: The flight nurse is transporting a patient from the sending hospital to the airport in an ambulance. The EMT asks what PPE they should wear for the patient. The patient is diagnosed with Influenza and is receiving mechanical ventilation. The EMT should wear:
options: N-95 mask, gown, gloves, eye protection
Surgical mask, gloves, gown, eye protection
questions.rationale: The required PPE for an aerosolized respiratory pathogen should be an N-95 mask, gown, gloves and eye protection. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 391

questions.stem: The transport team is dispatched to transfer an adult patient between facilities after a motor vehicle crash. Imaging at the community hospital showed liver and spleen lacerations. Initial stabilization involved administering 6 units of packed red blood cells and 6 units of fresh frozen plasma. During transport, the patient experiences ongoing hypotension. The flight nurse should consider which intervention NEXT?
questions.rationale: Massive transfusion exposes patients to significant amounts of citrate, a preservative used in blood products. Citrate binds calcium, rendering it inactive. This can lead to hypocalcemia, which causes hypotension from insufficient vasoconstriction, as well as prolonged QT interval, tetany, arrhythmias, and increased bleeding. Calcium chloride and calcium gluconate are both suitable options to replace the calcium that citrate has inactivated. Reference: Trauma Nursing Core Course, 9th ed. (2024), p. 99.

questions.stem: The flight crew is called to transport an adolescent who was clotheslined by a chain across their upper chest while riding a bicycle. The patient complains of dyspnea. They are anxious and subcutaneous emphysema is noted to their neck and upper thorax. The flight nurse suspects:
questions.rationale: While hemothorax, cardiac tamponade, and pulmonary contusions can be the result of blunt chest trauma, the presence of subcutaneous emphysema indicates a disruption of the trachea or bronchial tree. These injuries are often the result of a clothesline mechanism. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 255

questions.stem: The nurse is transporting a patient diagnosed with diabetic ketoacidosis. The patient is receiving an insulin infusion and has a blood glucose level that has decreased from 640 mg/dL to 350 mg/dL in the last hour. The nurse should prioritize assessing:
questions.rationale: Large shifts in glucose and fluid levels can lead to cerebral edema and can alter neurological status. Lung sounds, electrolyte levels and urine output are important, but do not take priority over the neurological exam. Reference: Critical Care Nursing: Diagnosis & Management, 8th Ed. (2018), p. 1040

questions.stem: The flight crew responds to an interfacility transfer of a patient struck in the face with a high-speed baseball. The patient was diagnosed with a small subdural hematoma and a zygomatic fracture. On assessment, the patient is neurologically intact with normal vital signs but complains of severe pain, loss of vision, and reduced eye movement on the affected side. Intraocular pressure is documented at 46 mmHg; the flight crew knows the MOST appropriate intervention prior to transport is:
questions.rationale: The patient is experiencing a retrobulbar hematoma. Signs and symptoms include severe pain, decrease or loss of vision, reduced eye movement, double vision, and IOP greater than 40mmHg. Emergent treatment is required to prevent permanent loss of vision; emergent treatment includes lateral canthotomy as an emergency decompression via the lateral canthotomy and/or medication administration that reduces IOP. The application of an eye shield will not decrease IOP. Placing the patient supine will result in increased IOP. Atropine does not affect IOP. Reference: Trauma Nursing Core Course, 9th ed. (2024), p. 133

questions.stem: Which of the following BEST describes the result of sympathetic dysfunction in a patient who has spinal cord injury?
questions.rationale: Vasodilation best describes this result. Vasodilation is the result of interruption of sympathetic outflow below the level of the injury and loss of auto-regulation. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 243

questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to transport a young child from an outlying hospital to a pediatric trauma center. The child was involved in an unrestrained motor vehicle accident and has numbness in bilateral feet. The sending nurse asks if they should remove spinal immobilization because the CT scan of the spine revealed no abnormalities. The flight nurse should:
options: request orders to repeat the CT scan
ask the sending physician about removal
questions.rationale: Young children can have spinal/neurological trauma without any findings on the CT/x-rays. This is called SCIWORA, Spinal Cord Injury without radiological findings. The immobilization should not be removed until instructed to do so by a physician who specializes in pediatric trauma. Reference: Wong's Nursing Care of Infants and Children, 12th Ed. (2024), p. 1,389

questions.category: Resuscitation Principles; Principles of Assessment and Patient Preparation
questions.stem: The flight crew is called for an interfacility transfer of a patient with reported hypotension. The patient is awake with a GCS of 15, blood pressure of 100/50 (66) mmHg, and a respiratory rate of 24 breaths/min. The flight crew recognizes this as a positive Quick Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (qSOFA). With this positive finding, the flight crew is MOST concerned for:
questions.rationale: Patients with suspected infection who are likely to have a prolonged ICU stay or to die in the hospital can be promptly identified at the bedside with a validated scoring tool called Quick Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (qSOFA). These high-risk adult patients have two or more of the following: alteration in mental status (Glasgow Coma Scale <15), systolic blood pressure less than or equal to 100 mm Hg, or respiratory rate greater than or equal to 22 breaths per minute. Positive qSOFA criteria should also prompt consideration of possible infection in patients not previously recognized as infected. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 6th Ed. (2024), p. 239

questions.stem: A patient is transferred from a critical access hospital to a level 1 trauma facility for a pelvic fracture from a motor vehicle collision. The patient's pelvis is stable but there is blood noted on the urethral meatus. The flight is estimated to take 45 minutes. Which order from the sending physician should the flight nurse question?
options: Insertion of an indwelling urinary catheter
questions.rationale: Blood at the meatus is indicative of a urethral injury or bladder rupture and a foley catheter should not be inserted without performing a urethrogram to confirm the urethra is intact. Bladder injuries can cause life-threatening bleeding into the pelvis, which may require surgery. A fluid bolus may be ordered for a patient expected to undergo surgery; however, a fluid bolus would not be appropriate. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 6th Ed. (2024), p. 202

questions.stem:
The flight team is called for a scene request of a car versus pedestrian. The patient is complaining of abdominal pain with pain to palpation of their pelvis. Vital signs are:

BP 82/59 mmHg

HR 127 beats/min

RR 24 breaths/min

SpO2 94% (room air)

What is the PRIORITY intervention?
questions.rationale: The patient is exhibiting signs of an unstable pelvis with a narrow pulse pressure. Control of bleeding is a top priority. All patients with an unstable pelvis, and those with a significant mechanism of injury and pelvic pain on palpation, should be immobilized with a commercial pelvic binder. Placing the patient on oxygen and administering analgesia are not priority interventions. Administering small amounts of IV crystalloids could support their blood pressure, but the patient is in need of a blood transfusion. Large amounts of crystalloids could dislodge blood clot formation and lead to hemodilution. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 271

questions.stem: Initial management of a patient suspected of having an air embolus would include
options: providing 100% O2 through a nonrebreating mask
positioning the patient in the head-forwards
questions.rationale: Initial management would include providing 100% O2 through a nonrebreathing mask. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 358

questions.stem: Upon initial assessment of a patient that was struck by lightning, the patient is unresponsive with diminished breath sounds on the right side. Needle decompression is performed with improvement. The cause of pneumothorax is related to:
options: Electrical current passing through the chest
Blunt force trauma from being knocked to the ground by lightning strike
Third degree burns to the chest wall
Increased chest pressure related to plastic damage from compartment syndrome
questions.rationale: Lightning strikes have voltage exposures as high as 1 billion volts. As a result of such high voltage, victims are commonly found with blunt force trauma related to being thrown. Electrical current passing through the chest will cause dysrhythmias, increased pressure from abdominal compartment syndrome will not manifest right away. While patients may sustain third degree burns from a lightning strike, this is not directly related to development of a pneumothorax. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 279

questions.stem: The flight crew is called to transport a patient from a rural care facility that was involved in a motor vehicle collision and sustained a Chance fracture. During transport, the nurse should perform frequent assessments of:
questions.rationale: A lumbar distraction fracture (Chance fracture) is often associated with intestinal injuries. To assess for intestinal injury, the nurse should frequently assess the patient's abdominal pain. Glasgow Coma Scale, upper extremity pulses, and depth of respirations would not be reliable exams to evaluate for intestinal injuries associated with Chance fractures. Reference: Trauma Nursing: From Resuscitation Through Rehabilitation, 5th Ed. (2019), p. 461

questions.stem: The flight nurse is called to transport a patient who has been stabbed multiple times in the abdomen. Upon initial assessment, the bowel is protruding from the abdominal wall. The flight nurse should perform the following for transport:
options: Cover the exposed bowel with sterile solution soaked gauze
Make incisions around the wound to allow the bowel to swell
Place a pressure dressing over the exposed bowel
Gently push the exposed bowel back into the abdominal wall
questions.rationale: The exposed bowel should be covered with a sterile solution in order to protect it before surgical intervention. The bowel should never be manipulated back into the abdomen, and should not be compressed unless to stop active bleeding. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 257

questions.stem: A patient presents to the emergency department complaining of increased pain, numbness and tingling following a tibial fracture one day prior. Physical exam reveals swelling, diminished pulses, decreased capillary refill and coolness to touch in the affected extremity. They are being transferred to a tertiary facility for definitive care. The flight nurse understands that the priority intervention is to:
options: Place a warm compress to the site
Place the extremity at the level of the heart
questions.rationale: The patient is exhibiting signs and symptoms of compartment syndrome. The extremity should be placed at the level of the heart (elevating too high can constrict arterial inflow and leaving in a dependent position can cause venous congestion, both of which worsen limb ischemia). Elastic bandages will increase compression and exacerbate the problem. Warm compresses will increase blood flow to the extremity and increase the internal pressure. IV fluids should be increased to maintain peripheral perfusion. Reference: Critical Care Transport, 2nd Edition (2018), p. 157 and https://www.uptodate.com/contents/acute-compartment-syndrome-of-the-extremities

questions.category: Medical Emergencies; Environmental and Toxicological Emergencies
questions.stem: A patient is being transferred for a higher level of care following an aspirin overdose. The most important medication to continue during transport is:
questions.rationale: Cautious alkalization with sodium bicarbonate is both helps acidosis and enhance salicylate excretion. N-acetylcysteine is for acetaminophen. Activated charcoal is given for charcoal toxicity. Activated charcoal is appropriate within 3 hours of ingestion, should not be given unless extended release tablets are suspected. Reference: Sheehy's Emergency Nursing: Principles and Practice, 7th Edition (2019), p. 524; Magdelaine, Bruno et al. 'Management of pharmaceutical and recreational drug poisoning.' Annals of Intensive Care vol. 10, 1 15; 23 Nov. 2020, doi:10.1186/s13613-020-00782-9.

questions.stem: The transport nurse is caring for a patient with stab wounds to the chest who is hypotensive, tachycardic with a narrow pulse pressure, and has distended neck veins. The patient goes into pulseless electrical activity cardiac arrest. Chest compressions are initiated and the patient is easily ventilated with a bag-valve mask. The nurse should anticipate the need for
questions.rationale: The clinical findings described are consistent with a pericardial tamponade, for which the immediate treatment is a pericardiocentesis. A pericardial window is the definitive treatment for a pericardial tamponade; however, this is performed by a cardiothoracic surgeon. Tube thoracostomy and needle decompression are treatments for a pneumothorax/tension pneumothorax, not a pericardial tamponade. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 253

questions.stem: The flight nurse arrives at a hospital to transport a patient to a Level I trauma center. The patient sustained a stab wound to the abdomen and has received 3 L of normal saline and 5 units of packed red blood cells. The nurse observes bleeding around the IV site and at the patient's nose. Before transport, the nurse should request:
questions.rationale: The patient is likely in disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) and requires additional clotting factors. The ideal ratio of blood products is 1:1:1. DIC happens where there is a depletion of clotting factors and hemostasis is impaired. Packed red blood cells, warmed normal saline and calcium chloride may be used but will not reverse DIC. Reference: Emergency Nursing Core Curriculum, 7th Ed. (2018), p. 293

questions.category: Medical Emergencies; Environmental and Toxicological Emergencies
questions.stem: While completing a secondary physical exam on a patient with frostbite to their feet, the flight nurse notices that the skin on the patients' feet is red and has developed clear blisters. What stage of frostbite does this patient have?
questions.rationale: Second-degree frostbite produces blistering or peeling of the skin and is characterized by hyperemia and vesicle or bleb formations. First-degree frostbite appears as hyperemia and edema but there is no blister formation. Third and fourth degree frostbite is indicated by hemorrhagic blisters on the digits (3rd degree) and carpals or tarsals (4th degree). Reference: Burn Nursing: Injury Prevention to Rehabilitation and Aftercare, 1st Ed. (2023), p. 602

questions.stem: A patient is being transported due to acute liver failure secondary to fulminant Hepatitis C infection. The patient begins seizing. The flight nurses recognize that seizures are MOST likely caused by which complication of the patient's condition?
questions.rationale: Hypoglycemia is a common side effect of acute liver failure due to impaired glucose synthesis. The complications are most likely to cause seizures. Reference: https://emcrit.org/ibccualf/endocrine, p. 1.

questions.category: Medical Emergencies; Environmental and Toxicological Emergencies
questions.stem: Which of the following signs are an indication for sodium bicarbonate administration in a tricyclic antidepressant ingestion?
options: a QRS complex greater than 100 milliseconds
pH 7.42, PCO2 25 mm Hg, HCO3- 28 mEq/L, PaO2 220 mm Hg
hypotension refractory to IV fluid boluses
questions.rationale: QRS >100ms is most often the indication for serum alkalization in TCA toxicity. However, about 88% of the poison control directors in the United States use a QRS of 100 milliseconds or greater as the cut-off for intravenous sodium bicarbonate. Arterial blood gases of pH 7.42, PCO2 25 mm Hg, HCO3- 28 mEq/L, PaO2 220 mm Hg do not warrant sodium bicarbonate administration. For hypotension refractory to intravenous saline, vasopressors with alpha-agonist effect (e.g., Neo-Synephrine, norepinephrine) may be used. Protracted vomiting is not an indication for sodium bicarbonate. Reference: Rosen's Emergency Medicine: Concepts & Clinical Practice, 9th Edition (2018), p. 1869-1870

questions.stem:
The flight nurse is called to transport a patient who was involved in a motor vehicle crash in which the patient was thrown from the vehicle. The patient reports decreased sensation below the waist and is unable to move their lower extremities. Vital signs:

HR 58 beats/min

BP 92/64 mmHg

RR 14 breaths/min

O2 sat 95% (4L nasal cannula)

The nurse should prioritize early care measures based on their understanding that:
options: Assessment will most likely reveal abnormal metal tone
The airway should be secured with RSI
The patient may be taking beta-blockers
questions.rationale: Spinal shock typically presents with hypotension and bradycardia, but it can conceal hemorrhagic shock. All patients involved in polytrauma should be suspected of hemorrhagic shock based on injury mechanism and assessment. Treatment should include blood products whenever possible. Although the other answers are plausible, hemorrhagic shock remains the top priority. Reference: Trauma Nursing: From Resuscitation Through Rehabilitation, 5th Ed. (2019), p. 468.

questions.stem: While taking report on a patient in a metabolic acidosis, the referring nurse mentions that the patient's pH is 7.15. The flight nurse recognizes that this indicates that:
options: Oxygen delivery at the tissue level is increased
The SpO2 will read higher for a given PaO2
The risk of pulmonary embolism is increased
The patient's respiratory rate will slow to compensate
questions.rationale: Decreasing pH leads to a right shift in the oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve. This decreases hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen, leading to elevated delivery at the tissue level. The SpO2 would read lower with a right shift. The respiratory rate should increase to compensate for the acidosis. Clotting factors are less active in the presence of acidosis, so the risk for PE is decreased. Reference: Critical Care Nursing: Diagnosis & Management, 8th Ed. (2018), p. 438

questions.stem: A patient who has an upper gastrointestinal bleed presents with clear lung sounds, a blood pressure of 110/80 mm Hg, a respiratory rate of 30 breaths/min and an oxygen saturation of 95%. The hemoglobin is 7.0 g/dL. Which of the following conditions could cause hypoxia?
questions.rationale: Hypemic hypoxia is correct. Hypemic hypoxia is due a decrease in the oxygen-carrying capacity of red blood cells through blood loss or dysfunction of the red blood cells. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 30

questions.stem: The nurse is called to transport a patient in hemorrhagic shock. The patient has refused blood products due to religious preferences and has received 1.5 liters of isotonic crystalloid solution. The NEXT appropriate intravenous treatment to initiate is:
questions.rationale: Norepinephrine will cause vasoconstriction to assist in shunting blood to vital organs in the patient in hemorrhagic shock. The patient has stated they do not want blood products and therefore PRBCs should not be initiated without consent. Additional normal saline can cause cellular swelling and death, leading to worsening outcomes, and perfusion. Sodium bicarb is not indicated in the patient with hemorrhagic shock. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 6th Ed. (2024), p. 238

questions.stem: Which medication would work MOST effectively to increase peripheral vascular tone?
questions.rationale: Norepinephrine (Levophed) would be most effective. Norepinephrine (Levophed) is a non-selective adrenergic agonist that is used to increase peripheral vascular tone and blood pressure. Dobutamine (Dobutrex) is a beta-1 adrenergic agonist that increases the force of cardiac contraction in congestive heart failure. Nicardipine (Cardene) is a calcium channel blocker used to lower blood pressure by decreasing vascular tone. Nitroprusside sodium (Nitropress) is a vasodilator used to lower blood pressure by decreasing vascular tone. Reference: Critical Care Nursing: Diagnosis & Management, 8th Ed. (2018), p. 402

questions.stem:
The flight crew is called to transport a patient diagnosed with endocarditis. Upon assessment, the patient exhibits jugular vein distention, edema, and shortness of breath. The patient has received 500 mL of IV fluid. Vital signs:

HR: 90 beats/min

BP: 95/60 mmHg

RR: 25 breaths/min

O2 Sat: 94% on 4L nasal cannula

The nurse should consider administering which medication?
questions.rationale: Norepinephrine is the preferred medication for supporting patients in cardiogenic shock related to endocarditis. Reference: Critical Care Nursing: Diagnosis & Management, 9th Ed. (2022), p. 397.

questions.stem: The nurse is called to transport a patient with a SCUBA diving related injury. The patient requires transport to a decompression chamber. The nurse recognizes that the flight plan should include:
options: Plot the most direct routing over the mountains
Flying at the lowest altitude possible
questions.rationale: The patient with a dive injury should be kept at as close to sea level as possible to avoid further injury. The nitrogen dissolved in the tissue will form bubbles in the patient's blood, possibly causing an embolism the further above sea level the patient goes. The patient should be provided with a high percentage of oxygen to breathe as well. If in doubt, contact the DAN (Diver Alert Network) emergency line for help with dive injury care. The definitive treatment is a hyperbaric chamber as soon as possible. Reference: Rosen's Emergency Medicine: Concepts & Clinical Practice, 9th Edition (2018), p. 1787

questions.stem:
The flight nurse is called to the scene at a rural house. The patient is agitated and has tremors. Upon assessment, a goiter is noted. Vital signs are as follows:

BP 140/86 mm Hg

HR 130 beats/min, irregular

RR 30 breaths/min

T (oral) 102.2°F (39°C)

O2 sat 98% (room air)

The PRIORITY medications for the nurse to administer are:
questions.rationale: The patient is experiencing a thyroid storm. The priority is to decrease the heart rate and temperature. Steroids are used the reduce thyroid hormone and prevent adrenal insufficiency. Aspirin is contraindicated because it is associated with thyroid hormone displacement. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 3/78

questions.stem: The flight nurse is called to transport a 5 kg patient from an outlying hospital. The nurse has an infant securement device rated from 10-20kg. The nurse's NEXT action should be to:
options: have the mother hold the infant during transport
questions.rationale: If the nurse is unable to safely transport a patient due to size, then they should refuse the transport. The safety of the patient is the responsibility of the medical crew. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 135

questions.stem: A farmer recently recovered from influenza was feeling well enough to work in the field, but has now developed substernal chest pain and shortness of breath. The electrocardiogram (ECG) reveals global ST elevation. What does the flight nurse suspect to be the likely cause?
questions.rationale: A small illness often precedes pericarditis and leads to widespread ST segment changes on an electrocardiogram (ECG). Unlike acute coronary syndrome, the pain from pericarditis is reproducible and can be relieved by rest and repositioning. Treatment options may include cardiac catheterization, but the condition is not caused by coronary artery occlusion. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK431081/, p. 1

questions.stem: The flight crew is transporting a patient who complains of anterior chest pain. The patient reports that the pain is worse with inspiration and radiates to both shoulders. The patient is hot to touch and reports dyspnea. The 12-lead reveals ST elevation in V2, V3, V4, V5, V6, I, II, III, aVL, and aVF. The flight crew recognizes the MOST likely cause of the chest pain is:
questions.rationale: Pericarditis typically presents with anterior chest pain with radiation to the neck, arms, or shoulders; pain may be intensified by deep inspiration. Associated symptoms of pericarditis are fever (i.e., 101°-102° or 38.3°-38.9°C), pericardial friction rub. ECG often reveals ST-segment elevation in all leads except V1 and aVR. Reference: Sheehy's Emergency Nursing: Principles and Practice, 7th Edition (2019), p. 239

questions.stem: The flight team is requested to transport a patient with an ischemic stroke directly to an interventional neuroradiology lab. Report to the crew includes right sided deficits that remained after full dose thrombolysis was administered; GCS 15. Upon arrival, the patient is found in a fetal position with progressively worsening respirations are noted. The patient is now flexing both arms and legs towards their chest. Based on this finding, the flight nurse should:
options: Notify the accepting physician prior to transfer
Cancel the transport and monitorize when the patient stabilizes
Notify the interventional neuroradiology team and transport as planned
Transport as planned and prioritize airway protection
questions.rationale: The accepting interventional neuroradiologist needs to be advised prior to departure from the sending facility. The treatment plan for this patient will change. Hemorrhage, herniation after IV thrombolysis can be a severe, life-threatening situation. Neurosurgical consultation, airway protection, additional CT scans and correction of coagulopathy will be needed for and treated. Based off of this finding, the transport destination of the patient could potentially change. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 287-297.

questions.stem: The flight nurse is called to transport a patient diagnosed with seizures. Upon arrival, referring staff states the patient has had 4 tonic-clonic seizures in the last hour. As the nurse begins their assessment, the patient suffers an additional tonic-clonic seizure lasting approximately 45 seconds. They are now obtunded, with snoring respirations. The primary intervention for this patient is:
questions.rationale: Rapid sequence intubation (RSI) is indicated at this point in the patient's hospitalization due to prolonged hypoxia to tissue cells related to multiple seizures, unresponsive presentation, and inability to maintain a patient airway. Maintaining a patent airway is the main intervention for this patient during transport. This patient should be treated aggressively with benzodiazepines and anti-epileptic medications, however, RSI is the primary intervention. Administering flumazenil is contraindicated and could induce seizures. Inserting an OPA could cause the patient to gag and does not provide a definitive airway. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 205

questions.stem: The flight crew is transporting a patient with a popliteal dislocation. Which of the following confirms adequate perfusion distal to the injury?
options: An ankle arterial pressure of 65 mmHg
questions.rationale: All patients with a knee injury should be considered high risk for popliteal artery injury. Distal pulses, skin color, and capillary refill should be checked frequently. The ankle brachial index (ABI) can be measured by obtaining an upper extremity blood pressure, followed by a second blood pressure on the calf of the injured extremity just above the ankle. To determine the ABI, divide the lower extremity systolic blood pressure by the upper extremity systolic blood pressure. An ABI greater than 0.90 has been associated with low risk of popliteal artery injury. A normal compartment pressure is between 0 and 8 mmHg. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 270

questions.stem: The flight nurse is preparing to transport a patient who has been treated for a pit viper envenomation with crotalidae polyvalent immune fab (CroFab). The nurse should observe for which potential complication of antivenin administration?
questions.rationale: Serum sickness can affect patients receiving antivenin therapy. Symptoms include fever, joint pain, rash, nausea, and vomiting. Fasciculations, compartment syndrome and hypotension can be complications of the envenomation, but are not the result of serum sickness. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 425

questions.stem: The transport team is transporting an unresponsive patient that had sustained a significant blow to the head. The patient was intubated prior to transport. The ETCO2 was initially 35 mm Hg. The patient is now bradycardic with a widening of the pulse pressure. Which of the following interventions should the transport nurse do at this time?
options: Increase the rate on the ventilator
Increase the rate of fluid replacement
questions.rationale: The nurse should increase the rate on the ventilator. The patient is showing signs of herniation. It is appropriate to increase the rate on the ventilator to hyperventilate to ultimately decrease intracranial pressure. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 195

questions.stem: An air-medical team responds to a hazardous materials incident at a chemical plant where a worker has been exposed to hydrogen cyanide gas. The patient has been removed from the contaminated atmosphere, and skin decontamination has occurred. The patient has been intubated and hyperventilated with 100% O2. The NEXT step in the therapy for this patient is the administration of
questions.rationale: The administration of hydroxocobalamin is the next step as this is the preferred antidote for cyanide toxicity. Glucagon is the antidote for beta blocker overdose. Chelating agents are utilized in iron poisoning. Benzodiazepine antagonists are utilized in benzodiazepine overdose. Reference: Rosen's Emergency Medicine: Concepts & Clinical Practice, 9th Edition (2018), p. 1929-1931

questions.stem:
The flight crew arrives to the bedside for a patient who presents with acute heart failure. Vital signs are:

BP: 158/70 mmHg

HR: 92 beats/min

RR: 28 breaths/min

SpO2: 84% (6 liters nasal canula)

GCS: 15

The BEST intervention for this patient is:
questions.rationale: In the setting of acute heart failure, signs and symptoms of respiratory failure should be treated with noninvasive positive pressure ventilation (NPPV) unless contraindicated. It has been shown to decrease both in-hospital mortality and need for intubation. Intubation should be a last resort and only considered when NPPV has failed or is contraindicated. BVM ventilation is not indicated in this case. A non-rebreathing mask does not provide the pressure within the lungs needed to assist with oxygenation like NPPV does. Reference: Rosen's Emergency Medicine: Concepts & Clinical Practice, 9th Edition (2018), p. 1048

questions.stem: Upon reaching altitude, the endotracheal cuff pressure reads 32 cm of H2O. Which of the following actions, if any, is required?
questions.rationale: Deflating the cuff slightly is correct because the recommended ETT cuff pressure is 20-30 cm H2O. Higher pressures may cause complications such as mucosal damage and tracheal ischemia. Replacing the end of the endotracheal tube is incorrect because there is no indication that the ETT is not functioning properly. Inflating the cuff slightly is incorrect because the current cuff pressure already exceeds what is recommended. No intervention is incorrect because the current cuff pressure exceeds what is recommended. Therefore, the cuff should be deflated slightly to avoid complications. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 185

questions.stem: The team is transporting a patient with a 3-day history of fever, weight loss, and decreased appetite. Laboratory studies reveal a potassium level of 3.1 mEq/L, glucose level of 524 mg/dL, pH of 7.2, and normal lipase level. The transport nurse should suspect
questions.rationale: The signs and symptoms that the patient is experiencing are consistent with diabetic ketoacidosis. Reference: ASTNA Patient Transport: Principles and Practice, 5th Ed. (2018), p. 211

questions.stem: In flight, the nurse notices a high pressure ventilator alarm. The nurse understands this is MOST likely caused by:
options: an endotracheal tube that is too small
questions.rationale: Having an ETT tube that is too small for the patient can cause a high pressure alarm. All the other options would cause a low pressure alarm.
